Legal_Issue: Whether the CHRC erred in refusing to reactivate the complaint under section 41(1)(d)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide credible evidence supporting her claims
Decision_Outcome: CHRC's decision not to reactivate the complaint was upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to show grounds for reactivation
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence; no proof of duress or non-fulfillment
Legal_Rule: Section 41(1)(d) allows refusal if complaint is trivial, frivolous, vexatious, or made in bad faith
Grounds_for_Claim: Duress and non-fulfillment of Memorandum of Agreement
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach of procedural fairness found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Memorandum of Agreement, lack of evidence of duress or breach
Applicant_Challenge: Seeking reactivation of a previously settled complaint
Court_Result: Dismissed application, ordered costs against Applicant
Defendant_Response: Complaint resolved by agreement; no evidence of invalidity
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (Memorandum of Agreement), assertions without corroboration
Remedy_Requested: Reactivation of discrimination and harassment complaint
Legal_Provision: Section 41(1)(d) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Claimant_Status: Applicant before CHRC and Federal Court
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Trivial, frivolous, vexatious, or made in bad faith
Applicable_Process: Complaint dismissal under s. 41(1)(d), followed by judicial review
